prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
WIBTA, for leaving my fiance of 7 years.
My fiance and I have been together for 7 years now and have an almost 6 year old son together.

Almost 3 years ago now we had broken up for about a month. During this time he began to talk to a girl that he's known for most of his life. We got back together, and I expected him to break off all contact with her. Which I thought was understandable.

2 weeks in and he still has her on all social media including snapchat. We fought and fought over it and he eventually deleted her. Or so I thought.

Last October, we had been growing rather distant and I took it upon myself to snoop through his phone.

And there she is. She had blocked me on social media so that I couldn't see them following each other. He had literally liked every single one of her pictures, not any of mine during the same time period to be clear, and she liked his as well. Including a picture of his Snapchat code asking people to add him.

I confront him. He becomes angry and defensive but swears hell get rid of her.

About a month later I decide to check again. And she's still there. So I told him I was leaving him.

He left for about 3 days. And we eventually talked things through and he again swore to delete her and block her for good.

3 weeks ago, I saw that he had liked pictures of the girl's sister on Instagram. He says he had remembered liking them from a long time ago and had been trying to unlike them so I would never find them and in doing so accidentally re liked the pictures, and I believed him.

Last night. He has both the girl AND her sister unblocked AGAIN on social media. Meaning he went out of his way to go through his settings, get to privacy, open his list of blocked users and unblocked those two in particular.

WIBTA for ending a 7 year relationship with the father of my son because he can't seem to let go of some other girl? Even though the only thing I really have evidence of is them staying in contact, not actually cheating?

I'm at a complete loss.
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's try to figure this out. The question is whether the author (the person in the WIBTA scenario) is in the wrong for leaving their fiancé after seven years. The main issue seems to be the fiancé's ongoing contact with another girl, even after multiple promises to cut it off.

First, the relationship has a long history, seven years, with a child together. That's a significant commitment. The breakup was after a month three years ago, but they reconciled. The author wanted the fiancé to stop all contact with the girl, which he did temporarily but then continued in different ways. The author found evidence of him liking the girl's photos, blocking/unblocking her, and even liking her sister's posts. Each time, the fiancé gave explanations, like trying to unlike posts accidentally, but the pattern repeats.

The key points here are trust and boundaries. The author felt that the fiancé wasn't respecting the boundaries set in the relationship. Even without cheating, the ongoing contact and the fiancé's inability to fully cut ties might be causing emotional harm. The author's decision to leave is based on the fact that the fiancé keeps breaking his promises, leading to a loss of trust.

On the other hand, the fiancé might argue that there's no actual infidelity, just contact. Maybe he believes it's not a big deal, or he's trying but not succeeding. However, the repeated actions despite promises could be seen as a lack of respect for the partner's feelings and boundaries.

In relationships, trust is crucial. If one partner can't honor their commitments regarding contact with someone else, especially after multiple instances, it's reasonable for the other partner to feel betrayed. The author is prioritizing their own emotional well-being and the health of the relationship by leaving when trust can't be maintained.

So, considering the pattern of behavior and the breach of trust, the author isn't necessarily in the wrong. The fiancé's actions, even without cheating, have caused repeated harm. Therefore, the answer might be B (No), the author is not in the wrong.
